subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
author: April Abercrombie
full_text:
------=_NextPart_000_009C_01C9D19F.3DD3B660
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

I am sorry to hear about your poison ivy!

Thanks for any help you can give=
 us on this.

April

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Jon 
  To: EVP=
-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 6:28 PM
  Subject: Re: [=
EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON






  Hi April,

  I have bee=
n out today, first day my poison ivy would let me back out of the house.  I=
 made good on my escape, LOL.  If everyone will bear with me I think I reca=
ll the files, involved.  This happened just a little over a year ago, and I=
 think I still have the files.  When I find them I will let you know the fi=
le types and the destination and origin of the files.  I had a computer cra=
sh since that time and I will have to back to backup files to extract and r=
estore the files. I think that I got a copy of the file that our member had=
 that was a total loss as a copy, with the data loss.  The data loss was gr=
eat enough that the file did not come close to the original.  I got in my c=
ar and drove over to my team members home to listen to the file I ad sent h=
im by e-mail through Yahoo I believe. I 'll verify that too.

  I will try =
to get you guys the information on the files by tomorrow night.  I hope eve=
ryone had a great weekend.


  Regards,
  Jon in Texas








------------=
------------------------------------------------------------------
  From: =
April Abercrombie <april@...>
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoog=
roups.com
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 3:50:03 PM
  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] =
File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON



  I have not personally experienced t=
he loss myself. Jon from this list is the one who originally told me about =
it. I have also heard of it happening to a few other people. After my conve=
rsation with Jon, I talked to a computer professional, and he told me that =
you can experience loss in attached files.

  I don't know if you would be =
able to tell loss of quality in an audio file with a bit-level comparison. =
Just because the data has been replaced, doesn't have to mean it is perfect=
.

  Did you listen to the before and after results?

  Jon-Please relay yo=
ur experience with the loss of quality on emailed files.


    ----- Origin=
al Message ----- 
    From: Rj 
    To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
    Sent:=
 Sunday, May 10, 2009 2:38 PM
    Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rul=
es


          I can't vouch for your computer or servers, but I just did s=
ome tests, and sent a 2.1MB wav file from MSN to Yahoo and back, once allow=
ing compression, and once turning it off.   I was able to verify that one w=
as compressed and one was not, by checking the sizes when they arrived at Y=
ahoo. Once they came back to MSN, I then did a bit-level comparison of the =
original, and the ones sent around email.  They were all identical, which i=
ndicates lossless compression.

          If you have a file you'd like me =
to test for you, let me know.  But I wouldn't take someone's word for how y=
our server's work, without testing them yourself.



          --- On Sun, =
5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


=
            From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
=
            Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
            To: EVP=
-ITC@yahoogroups .com
            Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 12:50 PM



 =
           For executables, you may be right. However, for wav files, the c=
ompression during email is not loss less. 

            I used to think as =
you do, in that the emailed attachment of a wav file would not loose anythi=
ng. After a lengthy discourse with another member here, I learned that I wa=
s wrong. The reason why I did not realize it in the first place is that whe=
n I would email a wav file, I would intentionally keep it in very small seg=
ments, to keep file size down. This was just for ease of transfer. But beca=
use of this, I had not experienced any noticeable loss.

            Now it=
 may be in some cases, depending on the servers or what have you that the f=
ile goes through, that the loss may be less or more. But once the attachmen=
t is downloaded, the quality has been found to be less then the original wa=
v.

            Again though you can only really tell when the wav file is =
large.

            ----- Original Message ----- 
              From: Rj 
 =
             To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
              Sent: Sunday, May =
10, 2009 1:36 PM
              Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
=


                    The kind of compression that occurs during an email a=
ttachment is "lossless": it compress the file cleverly without losing infor=
mation.  For example, if I had a program in some .exe files, and I sent it =
over email, it could compress it.  But if it lost even one bit, the resulti=
ng exe file would not execute again after it was uncompressed on the other =
side.

                    This kind of compression does things like lookin=
g for common patterns in the file, and replacing them with a token.  A roug=
h example would be if it found "Howdy Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it coul=
d replace all the occurances with say $HN1.  And also write a little dictio=
nary in there someplace that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neighbor".

               =
     When the file gets to its destination it can be uncompressed, and all =
occurences of $HN1 are replaced with "Howdy Neighbor".  So it was compresse=
d (instead of 14 characters each, it only needed 4, plus the dictionary), b=
ut lost no data.

                    Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. are =
not lossless.  Depending on the level of compression, some level of data is=
 lost, and so cannot be recovered or reconstructed later.

                =
    Rick



                    --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <apr=
il@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                      From: Apr=
il Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
                     =
 Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                      To: EVP-=
ITC@yahoogroups .com
                      Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 10:2=
6 AM



                      Another thing:

                      I recen=
tly found this out. When you email a file, if it is not saved as a compress=
ed format, the email filtering process will actually compress the file auto=
matically.

                      So even if you have attached a wav. file,=
 it will loose resolution over the email process. It will not sound exactly=
 the same as the original wav. file. How much it differs depends on the siz=
e of the file you are attaching. If it is a very large file, it will sound =
much different.

                      The only exception to this is if the=
 wav. file is small enough that the filtering process will ignore it. It ha=
s to be pretty small though, like under 1 MB (I am not exactly sure of the =
threshold).

                      The best way to share files over the int=
ernet if you want them as close to the original as possible is to upload th=
em directly to a website.

                        ----- Original Message -=
---- 
                        From: Rj 
                        To: EVP-ITC=
@yahoogroups .com 
                        Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 10:54=
 AM
                        Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules



=
                              Pixelization doesn't clean-up the data: it re=
places it.  Imagine taking a picture of a field of flowers, and beginning t=
o add levels or pixelization to the picture.  Soon, you would not be able t=
o tell there were flowers there at all.  You would see a lot of colored blo=
cks.

                              Or in the other direction, imagine you =
are looking at a competely randomize bunch of pixes on your screen: a compl=
ete screen of truely random static snow.  Pixelizing this, after a while, y=
ou would again start to see colored blocks.

                              =
What's happening is that it is processing an area of the image, taking (for=
 instance) the average value of that entire area, and replacing all the blo=
cks in that area with the average.  In video processing, this would result =
in a field of multi-colored flowers being replaced by, for instance, a big =
greyish-bluish block, with no resemblance to flowers.  In the noise example=
, it maybe replace all the random pixels with another big greyish-bluish bl=
ock.  If you did not know beforehand what the original picture was, you cou=
ldn't tell whether your pixelized image was really a field of flowers, a ch=
evy, the sky with clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.

                   =
           It works the same with the sound files.  Taking something as com=
plex as speech, and replacing frequencies with their averages, loses the sp=
eech the farther you go, until you head strange fluctuating square waves.  =
Doing the same to random static will eventually produce the same thing.  An=
d random fluctuating square waves can sound a bit like speech - or at least=
, you could have fun sharing with each other what you thing they 'sound lik=
e'.





                              --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bul=
letbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:


                                From: Misty D=
awn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com>
                                Subject: Re: [=
EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                                To: EVP-ITC@y=
ahoogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009,=
 9:29 AM


                                I always save the whole file in =
wav format then do my clips as mp3. Then I have the original for analysis. =


                                As far as pixelization of non sounds/whit=
e noise whos to say that isnt being manipulated by them as well LOL. Water =
is a form of white noise. I seem to remember some experiments done with bla=
nk tapes/film, no recording done yet there were voices/images there. I find=
 it all interesting.

                                Just a thought. Ok of=
f to work now!
                                Misty

                     =
           --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com> wrote:


         =
                       From: Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com>
                     =
           Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                    =
            To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                Da=
te: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 11:47 AM


                                Be a b=
it careful of formats like mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the =
sounds though.   While some formats (like wav) can store the audio very clo=
se to the way it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress the file, and in s=
o doing lose some of the sonic details.  This may not be a big deal in musi=
c, where the audio is fairly clear to begin with.  But with sound sources w=
ith a lot of noise (like evps), this can not only obscure any real sounds, =
but pixelize non-sounds (like white noise) and make them start to sound lik=
e speech.

                                So mp3 might be good for sharing=
 the data, once you've already formed an opinion based on an analysis of th=
e wav file.  But mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis.  It can lead to =
many false positives and misinterpretations.

                             =
   --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:


      =
                          From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com>
       =

      =
                          To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                    =
            Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 8:26 AM


                         =
       Thanks =3D)

                                 You will get the hang =
of it. Kristen is right thats how you save it. For most softwares its under=
 save as or export as. If you still have trouble use one of the links I pos=
ted to help ya out.

                                Misty

 they will have to be removed. Our group only has a very limited amount of =

                        =
        Misty

u nds_like_ three_squeeking_ words.wav

oaded by : snowfirel <SnowfireL@aol. com> 
                                =
Description : Test1 these are last 3 words, can't make them out, haven't ch=

                           =
     You can access this file at the URL:

ttp://groups. yahoo.com/ group/EVP- ITC/files/ Snowfirel/ test1sounds_ like=

=3D0>
                <TBODY>
                <TR>
                  <TD vA=
lign=3Dtop>The kind of compression that occurs during an 
                 =
   email attachment is "lossless": it compress the file 
                  =
  cleverly without losing information.  For example, if I 
           =
         had a program in some .exe files, and I sent it over email, 
     =
               it could compress it.  But if it lost even one bit, the=
 
                    resulting exe file would not execute again after it w=
as 
                    uncompressed on the other side.<BR><BR>This kind of=
 
                    compression does things like looking for common patte=
rns in 
                    the file, and replacing them with a token.&nbsp=
; A rough 
                    example would be if it found "Howdy Neighbor=
" in a file 20 
                    times, it could replace all the occuran=
ces with say 
                    $HN1.  And also write a little dicti=
onary in there 
                    someplace that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neigh=
bor".<BR><BR>When the 
                    file gets to its destination it =
can be uncompressed, and all 
                    occurences of $HN1 are re=
placed with "Howdy Neighbor".  
                    So it was compress=
ed (instead of 14 characters each, it only 
                    needed 4, p=
lus the dictionary), but lost no 
                    data.<BR><BR>Some for=
mats, like jpeg and mp3. are not 
                    lossless.  Depen=
ding on the level of compression, some 
                    level of data i=
s lost, and so cannot be recovered or 
                    reconstructed la=
ter.<BR><BR>Rick<BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On 
                    <B>Sun, 5/10/09=
, April Abercrombie 
                    <I><april@abercrombiegh ostrese=
arch. com></I></B> 
                    wrote:<BR>
                    <=
BLOCKQUOTE 
                      style=3D"BORDER-LEFT: rgb(16,16,255) 2px =
solid"><BR>From: 
                      April Abercrombie <april@abercro=
mbiegh ostresearch. 
                      com><BR>Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC=
] File uploading 
                      rules<BR>To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .c=
om<BR>Date: Sunday, May 
                      10, 2009, 10:26 AM<BR><BR>
 =
                     <DIV id=3Dyiv819860743>
                      <DIV id=
=3Dygrp-text>
                      <P></P>
                      <DIV><FON=
T size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">Another 
                      thing:</FONT>=
</DIV>
                      <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT=
> </DIV>
                      <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro"=
>I recently found this 
                      out. When you email a file, i=
f it is not saved as a 
                      compressed format, the email =
filtering process will 
                      actually compress the file au=
tomatically.</FONT></DIV>
                      <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D=
"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>
                      <DIV><FONT size=3D2 =
face=3D"Myriad Pro">So even if you have 
                      attached a w=
av. file, it will loose resolution over the 
                      email pr=
ocess. It will not sound exactly the same as the 
                      ori=
ginal wav. file. How much it differs depends on the 
                      =
size of the file you are attaching. If it is a 
                      very&=
nbsp;large file, it will sound much 
                      different.</FONT=
></DIV>
                      <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FON=
T> </DIV>
                      <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro=
">The only exception to 
                      this is if the wav. file is =
small enough that the 
                      filtering process will ignore =
it. It has to be pretty 
                      small though, like under 1&n=
bsp;MB (I am not exactly sure 
                      of the threshold).</FO=
NT></DIV>
                      <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro"></F=
ONT> </DIV>
                      <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad P=
ro">The best way to share 
                      files over the internet&nb=
sp;if you want them as close to 
                      the original as poss=
ible is to upload them directly to a 
                      website.</FONT>=
</DIV>
                      <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT=
><FONT size=3D2 
                      face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </D=
IV>

solid"

TABLE border=3D0 cellSpacing=3D0 cellPadding=3D0>
                         =
 <TBODY>
                          <TR>
                            <TD vAl=
ign=3Dtop><BR>Pixelization doesn't clean-up 
                              =
the data: it replaces it.  Imagine taking a 
                         =
     picture of a field of flowers, and beginning to 
                     =
         add levels or pixelization to the picture.  
                =
              Soon, you would not be able to tell there were 
             =
                 flowers there at all.  You would see a lot of 
      =
                        colored blocks.<BR><BR>Or in the other direction, 
=
                              imagine you are looking at a competely random=
ize 
                              bunch of pixes on your screen: a complet=
e screen 
                              of truely random static snow. =
 Pixelizing 
                              this, after a while, you would a=
gain start to see 
                              colored blocks.<BR><BR>Wha=
t's happening is that it 
                              is processing an ar=
ea of the image, taking (for 
                              instance) the a=
verage value of that entire area, 
                              and replac=
ing all the blocks in that area with the 
                              ave=
rage.  In video processing, this would 
                              =
result in a field of multi-colored flowers being 
                         =
     replaced by, for instance, a big greyish-bluish 
                     =
         block, with no resemblance to flowers.  In 
                 =
             the noise example, it maybe replace all the random 
          =
                    pixels with another big greyish-bluish 
               =
               block.  If you did not know beforehand what 
          =
                    the original picture was, you couldn't tell 
          =
                    whether your pixelized image was really a field of 
   =
                           flowers, a chevy, the sky with clouds, or a rand=
om 
                              bunch of pixels.<BR><BR>It works the same=
 with the 
                              sound files.  Taking somethin=
g as complex as 
                              speech, and replacing freque=
ncies with their 
                              averages, loses the speech =
the farther you go, 
                              until you head strange f=
luctuating square 
                              waves.  Doing the sam=
e to random static will 
                              eventually produce t=
he same thing.  And 
                              random fluctuating =
square waves can sound a bit 
                              like speech - o=
r at least, you could have fun 
                              sharing with =
each other what you thing they 'sound 
                              like'.=
<BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
                              5/10/=
09, Misty Dawn <I><bulletbabea@ <A 
                              href=
=3D"http://yahoo.com" 
                              target=3D_blank>yahoo.=
com</A>></I></B> wrote:<BR>

ext>

rmat

the 
                                original for analysis. </DIV>

                                <=
DIV>As far as pixelization of non sounds/white 
                           =
     noise whos to say that isnt being manipulated by 
                    =
            them as well LOL. Water is a form of white 
                   =
             noise. I seem to remember some experiments done 
             =
                   with blank tapes/film, no recording done 
         =
                       yet there were voices/images there. I find it 
     =
                           all interesting.</DIV>

               =
                 <TBODY>
                                <TR>
             =
                   <TD vAlign=3Dtop>Be a bit careful of formats like 
     =
                           mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the =

                                sounds though.   While some form=
ats 
                                (like wav) can store the audio very cl=
ose to the 
                                way it was recorded, formats li=
ke mp3 compress 
                                the file, and in so doing =
lose some of the sonic 
                                details.  This=
 may not be a big deal in 
                                music, where the=
 audio is fairly clear to begin 
                                with.&nbsp=
; But with sound sources with a lot of 
                                noi=
se (like evps), this can not only obscure any 
                            =
    real sounds, but pixelize non-sounds (like white 
                     =
           noise) and make them start to sound like 
                      =
          speech.<BR><BR>So mp3 might be good for sharing 
                =
                the data, once you've already formed an opinion 
          =
                      based on an analysis of the wav file.  But 
    =
                            mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis. =
 
                                It can lead to many false positives and 
=
                                misinterpretations.<BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
=
                                5/10/09, Misty Dawn <I><bulletbabea@ 
  =
                              yahoo.com></I></B> wrote:<BR>
